mainmatter.p: An interesting example named omega combinator of beta reduction is the following: ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) ((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x)))→β((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x))) ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) ((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x)))→β​((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x))) The result of the beta reduction is the same term as the original term, and never terminates.
Refer to Type Theory and Formal Proof.

The idea to generalize the behavior of functions in mathematics and logic led to the development of the lambda calculus. The lambda calculus is a formal system for expressing computation based on function abstraction and application using variable binding and substitution. In dealing with functions there are two construction principles and one evalutaion rule. Construction Principles: note that expressions do not force to be meaningful. Function Abstraction: \lambda x.Mλx.M\lambda x.Mλx.M Function Application: M NMNM NMN, this only produces a new expression, in which the function has not yet been executed. Evaluation Rule Beta Reduction: ( \lambda x.M)N \to M[x:=N](λx.M)N→M[x:=N]( \lambda x.M)N \to M[x:=N](λx.M)N→M[x:=N] The beta reduction makes use of the substitution M[x:=N]M[x:=N]M[x:=N]M[x:=N] which represents the result of replacing all free occurrences of xxxx in MMMM with NNNN. Note that the application is left associative, that is, MNPMNPMNPMNP means (MN)P(MN)P(MN)P(MN)P. And application has the highest precedence, that is, \lambda x.MNλx.MN\lambda x.MNλx.MN means \lambda x.(MN)λx.(MN)\lambda x.(MN)λx.(MN).

The multi-argument function \lambda x_1 \ldots x_n.Mλx1…xn.M\lambda x_1 \ldots x_n.Mλx1​…xn​.M is defined as \lambda x_1.( \lambda x_2.( \ldots ( \lambda x_n.M) \ldots ))λx1.(λx2.(…(λxn.M)…))\lambda x_1.( \lambda x_2.( \ldots ( \lambda x_n.M) \ldots ))λx1​.(λx2​.(…(λxn​.M)…)) (right associative), that is, simulated by a sequence of single-argument functions. The later function is called curried function and the process of transforming a multi-argument function into a sequence of single-argument functions is called currying.
Expressions in the lambda calculus is called terms. The set of terms is denoted \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ.

Let \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ be the set of lambda terms. Then \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ is defined inductively as follows: (VVVV is the set of variables) Variable: \forall x \in V, x \in \Lambda∀x∈V,x∈Λ\forall x \in V, x \in \Lambda∀x∈V,x∈Λ Abstraction: \forall x \in V, M \in \Lambda , \lambda x.M \in \Lambda∀x∈V,M∈Λ,λx.M∈Λ\forall x \in V, M \in \Lambda , \lambda x.M \in \Lambda∀x∈V,M∈Λ,λx.M∈Λ Application: \forall M,N \in \Lambda , (MN) \in \Lambda∀M,N∈Λ,(MN)∈Λ\forall M,N \in \Lambda , (MN) \in \Lambda∀M,N∈Λ,(MN)∈Λ

Another way to define \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ is to use the following grammar (The 3 possibilities are separated by |): \Lambda = V | \lambda V. \Lambda | \Lambda \LambdaΛ=V∣λV.Λ∣ΛΛ\Lambda = V | \lambda V. \Lambda | \Lambda \LambdaΛ=V∣λV.Λ∣ΛΛ
With the following recursive definition we can determine what the subterms of a give \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term are. Here we use a concept named multiset.

We define a map \text {Sub}Sub\text {Sub}Sub: Basis: \forall x \in V, \text {Sub} (x) = \{ x \}∀x∈V,Sub(x)={x}\forall x \in V, \text {Sub} (x) = \{ x \}∀x∈V,Sub(x)={x} Application: \forall M,N \in \Lambda , \text {Sub} (MN) = \text {Sub} (M) \cup \text {Sub} (N) \cup \{ MN \}∀M,N∈Λ,Sub(MN)=Sub(M)∪Sub(N)∪{MN}\forall M,N \in \Lambda , \text {Sub} (MN) = \text {Sub} (M) \cup \text {Sub} (N) \cup \{ MN \}∀M,N∈Λ,Sub(MN)=Sub(M)∪Sub(N)∪{MN} Abstraction: \forall x \in V,M \in \Lambda , \text {Sub} ( \lambda x.M) = \text {Sub} (M) \cup \{ \lambda x.M \}∀x∈V,M∈Λ,Sub(λx.M)=Sub(M)∪{λx.M}\forall x \in V,M \in \Lambda , \text {Sub} ( \lambda x.M) = \text {Sub} (M) \cup \{ \lambda x.M \}∀x∈V,M∈Λ,Sub(λx.M)=Sub(M)∪{λx.M} LLLL is a subterm of MMMM if L \in \text {Sub} (M)L∈Sub(M)L \in \text {Sub} (M)L∈Sub(M). If L \not \equiv ML≢ML \not \equiv ML≡M then we say LLLL is a proper subterm of MMMM.
The definition above uses a notation \equiv≡\equiv≡ which means syntactic equality here.

ul.li: \text {Sub} ( ( x \space z ) )Sub((x z))\text {Sub} ( ( x \space z ) )Sub((x z)) = \{ x,z, ( x \space z ) \}{x,z,(x z)}\{ x,z, ( x \space z ) \}{x,z,(x z)}

li.tex: \text {Sub} ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) = \{ \lambda x. ( x \space x ) , ( x \space x ) ,x,x \} Sub(λx.(x x))={λx.(x x),(x x),x,x} \text {Sub} ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) = \{ \lambda x. ( x \space x ) , ( x \space x ) ,x,x \} Sub(λx.(x x))={λx.(x x),(x x),x,x}

mainmatter.p: The substerm mapping satisfies the following lemma.

ul.li: Reflexivity: \forall M \in \Lambda ,M \in \text {Sub} (M)∀M∈Λ,M∈Sub(M)\forall M \in \Lambda ,M \in \text {Sub} (M)∀M∈Λ,M∈Sub(M)

Transitivity: \forall L,M,N \in \Lambda ,L \in \text {Sub} (M) \land M \in \text {Sub} (N) \implies L \in \text {Sub} (N)∀L,M,N∈Λ,L∈Sub(M)∧M∈Sub(N)  ⟹  L∈Sub(N)\forall L,M,N \in \Lambda ,L \in \text {Sub} (M) \land M \in \text {Sub} (N) \implies L \in \text {Sub} (N)∀L,M,N∈Λ,L∈Sub(M)∧M∈Sub(N)⟹L∈Sub(N)

mainmatter.p: Variable occurrences in a \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term can be divided into 3 categories: Bound Occurrences: xxxx is bound in MMMM if xxxx is the argument of an abstraction in MMMM. Free Occurrences: xxxx is free in MMMM if xxxx is not bound by any abstraction in MMMM. Binding Occurrences: something after a lambda notation \lambdaλ\lambdaλ We mainly focus on the free variables of a term.

Let FV(L)FV(L)FV(L)FV(L) be the set of free variables in a term LLLL. Variable: \forall x \in V, \text {FV} (x) = \{ x \}∀x∈V,FV(x)={x}\forall x \in V, \text {FV} (x) = \{ x \}∀x∈V,FV(x)={x} Application: \forall M,N \in \Lambda , \text {FV} (MN) = \text {FV} (M) \cup \text {FV} (N)∀M,N∈Λ,FV(MN)=FV(M)∪FV(N)\forall M,N \in \Lambda , \text {FV} (MN) = \text {FV} (M) \cup \text {FV} (N)∀M,N∈Λ,FV(MN)=FV(M)∪FV(N) Abstraction: \forall x \in V,M \in \Lambda , \text {FV} ( \lambda x.M) = \text {FV} (M) \setminus \{ x \}∀x∈V,M∈Λ,FV(λx.M)=FV(M)∖{x}\forall x \in V,M \in \Lambda , \text {FV} ( \lambda x.M) = \text {FV} (M) \setminus \{ x \}∀x∈V,M∈Λ,FV(λx.M)=FV(M)∖{x}

The \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term MMMM is closed if \text {FV} (M) = \emptysetFV(M)=∅\text {FV} (M) = \emptysetFV(M)=∅. A closed \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term is also called a combinator. The set of all combinators is denoted by \Lambda ^0Λ0\Lambda ^0Λ0.

Functions in \lambda \text {-calculus}λ-calculus\lambda \text {-calculus}λ-calculus have the property that the name of the binding variables is irrelevant. In order to describe this equality we need to define a relation called \alpha \text {-conversion}α-conversion\alpha \text {-conversion}α-conversion or \alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence\alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence, which is based on the process of renaming binding variables.

Let M ^{ x \to y }Mx→yM ^{ x \to y }Mx→y be the result of replacing all free occurrences of xxxx in MMMM with yyyy. The relation renaming is expression with the symbol =_ \alpha=α=_ \alpha=α​: \lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y }λx.M=αλy.Mx→y\lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y }λx.M=α​λy.Mx→y if y \not \in \text {FV} (M)y∉FV(M)y \not \in \text {FV} (M)y∈FV(M) and yyyy is not a binding variable in MMMM.
The definition of renaming should be extended to more general terms.

The \alphaα\alphaα equivalence is a relation between \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term, defined as follows: Renaming: \lambda x. M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y }λx.M=αλy.Mx→y\lambda x. M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y }λx.M=α​λy.Mx→y if y \not \in \text {FV} (M)y∉FV(M)y \not \in \text {FV} (M)y∈FV(M) and yyyy is not a binding variable in MMMM. Compatibility: If M =_ \alpha NM=αNM =_ \alpha NM=α​N then \lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda x.Nλx.M=αλx.N\lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda x.Nλx.M=α​λx.N and ML =_ \alpha NL, LM =_ \alpha LNML=αNL,LM=αLNML =_ \alpha NL, LM =_ \alpha LNML=α​NL,LM=α​LN. Reflexivity: M =_ \alpha MM=αMM =_ \alpha MM=α​M. Symmetry: If M =_ \alpha NM=αNM =_ \alpha NM=α​N then N =_ \alpha MN=αMN =_ \alpha MN=α​M. Transitivity: If M =_ \alpha NM=αNM =_ \alpha NM=α​N and N =_ \alpha LN=αLN =_ \alpha LN=α​L then M =_ \alpha LM=αLM =_ \alpha LM=α​L. The first principle is the basis of alpha equivalence, which is the same as renaming. The last 3 properties ensures that =_ \alpha=α=_ \alpha=α​ is an equivalence relation.

If M =_ \alpha NM=αNM =_ \alpha NM=α​N then we say MMMM and NNNN are \alpha \text {-equivalent}α-equivalent\alpha \text {-equivalent}α-equivalent or \alpha \text {-convertible}α-convertible\alpha \text {-convertible}α-convertible. MMMM is an \alpha \text {-variant}α-variant\alpha \text {-variant}α-variant of NNNN and vice versa.
In previous sections we informally mentioned the concept of substitution. Now we give a precise formulation

The substitution is defined by the following rules: M [ x := N ] : \equiv NM[x:=N]:≡NM [ x := N ] : \equiv NM[x:=N]:≡N y [ x := N ] : \equiv yy[x:=N]:≡yy [ x := N ] : \equiv yy[x:=N]:≡y if y \not \equiv xy≢xy \not \equiv xy≡x (PQ) [ x := N ] : \equiv ( P [ x := N ] )( Q [ x := N ] )(PQ)[x:=N]:≡(P[x:=N])(Q[x:=N])(PQ) [ x := N ] : \equiv ( P [ x := N ] )( Q [ x := N ] )(PQ)[x:=N]:≡(P[x:=N])(Q[x:=N]) ( \lambda y.P) [ x := N ] : \equiv \lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } [ x := N ](λy.P)[x:=N]:≡λz.Py→z[x:=N]( \lambda y.P) [ x := N ] : \equiv \lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } [ x := N ](λy.P)[x:=N]:≡λz.Py→z[x:=N] if \lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } =_ \alpha \lambda y.Pλz.Py→z=αλy.P\lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } =_ \alpha \lambda y.Pλz.Py→z=α​λy.P and z \not \in \text {FV} (N)z∉FV(N)z \not \in \text {FV} (N)z∈FV(N) The terms with form P [ x := N ]P[x:=N]P [ x := N ]P[x:=N] are not \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term, but we can regard them as a meta notation that appears in the substitution process and the result contains no such terms.

Renaming can be considered as a special case of substitution. We can show that M ^{ x \to u } =_ \alpha M [ x := u ]Mx→u=αM[x:=u]M ^{ x \to u } =_ \alpha M [ x := u ]Mx→u=α​M[x:=u] if the conditions of renaming are satisfied.
We may do sequential substitution in a term, that is, doing a number of substitutions consecutively. And we have the following lemma, which states that the order of substitution is important.

Let x ot \equiv yx≢yx ot \equiv yx≡y and assume x ot \in ext {FV} (L)x∉FV(L)x ot \in ext {FV} (L)x∈FV(L). Then L[y:=N][x:=M] \equiv L[x:=M][y:=N[x:=M]]L[y:=N][x:=M]≡L[x:=M][y:=N[x:=M]]L[y:=N][x:=M] \equiv L[x:=M][y:=N[x:=M]]L[y:=N][x:=M]≡L[x:=M][y:=N[x:=M]].

frontmatter.title: Untyped Lambda Calculus › \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term modulo \alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence\alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence

mainmatter.p: As we have seen, the relation =_ \alpha=α=_ \alpha=α​ is an equivalence relation. Hence we can define the set of equivalence classes of terms with respect to =_ \alpha=α=_ \alpha=α​. Now we can identify a term with its equivalence class. We still use \equiv≡\equiv≡ for syntactic equality modulo \alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence\alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence.
\alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence\alpha \text {-equivalence}α-equivalence is a congruence relation, which means that it is conserved by elementary process of term construction.

Let L =_ \alpha ML=αML =_ \alpha ML=α​M and N =_ \alpha PN=αPN =_ \alpha PN=α​P. LN =_ \alpha MP LN=αMP LN =_ \alpha MP LN=α​MP \lambda x.L =_ \alpha \lambda x.M λx.L=αλx.M \lambda x.L =_ \alpha \lambda x.M λx.L=α​λx.M L [ x := N ] =_ \alpha M [ x := P ] L[x:=N]=αM[x:=P] L [ x := N ] =_ \alpha M [ x := P ] L[x:=N]=α​M[x:=P]

The Barendregt Convention states that we should avoid using the same variable name in different abstractions. This is to avoid the confusion of free variables. It states that we choose the names for the binding variables in a \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term in such a manner that they are all different, and each of them differs from all free variables occurring in the term.

Since we have formally defined the substitution, we can rephrase the reduction as a relation on \lambda \text {-term}λ-term\lambda \text {-term}λ-term, namely \beta \text {-reduction}β-reduction\beta \text {-reduction}β-reduction.

One step beta reduction (\to _ \beta→β\to _ \beta→β​) is defined as follows: Basis: ( \lambda x.M)N \to _ \beta M [ x := N ] (λx.M)N→βM[x:=N] ( \lambda x.M)N \to _ \beta M [ x := N ] (λx.M)N→β​M[x:=N] Compatibility: If M \to _ \beta NM→βNM \to _ \beta NM→β​N then \lambda x.M \to _ \beta \lambda x.Nλx.M→βλx.N\lambda x.M \to _ \beta \lambda x.Nλx.M→β​λx.N, ML \to _ \beta NLML→βNLML \to _ \beta NLML→β​NL and LM \to _ \beta LNLM→βLNLM \to _ \beta LNLM→β​LN.

The term of the form ( \lambda x.M)N(λx.M)N( \lambda x.M)N(λx.M)N is called a redex (reducible expression). The term of the form M [ x := N ]M[x:=N]M [ x := N ]M[x:=N] is called the contractum (of the redex).

An interesting example named omega combinator of beta reduction is the following: ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) ((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x)))→β((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x))) ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) ((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x)))→β​((λx.(x x)) (λx.(x x))) The result of the beta reduction is the same term as the original term, and never terminates.
We can often perform a sequence of beta reductions. This leads to the definition.

The (zero-or-more-step) beta reduction (\twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta }↠β\twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta }↠β​) is a generalized version of the one step beta reduction. M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } NM↠βNM \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } NM↠β​N if there exists n \geq 0n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 and there are terms M_0,M_1, \ldots ,M_nM0,M1,…,MnM_0,M_1, \ldots ,M_nM0​,M1​,…,Mn​ such that M_0=MM0=MM_0=MM0​=M, M_n=NMn=NM_n=NMn​=N and M_i \to _ \beta M_{i+1}Mi→βMi+1M_i \to _ \beta M_{i+1}Mi​→β​Mi+1​ for 0 \leq i0≤i<n0 \leq i<n0≤i<n. In other words there exists a chain of one-step beta reductions from MMMM to NNNN. M \equiv M_0 \to _ \beta M_1 \to _ \beta \cdots \to _ \beta M_n \equiv N M≡M0→βM1→β⋯→βMn≡N M \equiv M_0 \to _ \beta M_1 \to _ \beta \cdots \to _ \beta M_n \equiv N M≡M0​→β​M1​→β​⋯→β​Mn​≡N

ul.li: Compatibility: \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta }↠β\twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta }↠β​ extends \to _ \beta→β\to _ \beta→β​, i.e. if M \to _ \beta NM→βNM \to _ \beta NM→β​N then M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } NM↠βNM \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } NM↠β​N.
Reflixivity: M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } M M↠βM M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } M M↠β​M

Transitivity: M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } N \land N \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P \implies M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P M↠βN∧N↠βP  ⟹  M↠βP M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } N \land N \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P \implies M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P M↠β​N∧N↠β​P⟹M↠β​P

mainmatter.p: We begin with the schema of iteration and then proceed the more complex schema of primitive recursion and general recursion. Refer to TAPL.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Function Composition

tree.mainmatter: Giving two functions f, gf,gf, gf,g we can compose then to get a new function f \circ g = f(g(x))f∘g=f(g(x))f \circ g = f(g(x))f∘g=f(g(x)). Using \lambdaλ\lambdaλ-notation, we can define the composition of two functions as follows: f \circ g = \lambda x.f(g(x)) f∘g=λx.f(g(x)) f \circ g = \lambda x.f(g(x)) f∘g=λx.f(g(x)) And the composition operation is also a lambda abstraction. \circ = B = \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) ∘=B=λf.λg.λx.f(g(x)) \circ = B = \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) ∘=B=λf.λg.λx.f(g(x)) Composing identity function with any function does not change the function. We expect the following equation to hold: f \circ I = f = I \circ f f∘I=f=I∘f f \circ I = f = I \circ f f∘I=f=I∘f where IIII is the identity function. This can be verified by the following calculation: \begin {align*} B \space f \space I &= ( \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x))) \space f \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(I(x)) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(x) \\ & =_ \eta f \end {align*} B f I=(λf.λg.λx.f(g(x))) f I→βλg.λx.f(g(x)) I→βλx.f(I(x))→βλx.f(x)=ηf \begin {align*} B \space f \space I &= ( \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x))) \space f \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(I(x)) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(x) \\ & =_ \eta f \end {align*} B f I​=(λf.λg.λx.f(g(x))) f I→β​λg.λx.f(g(x)) I→β​λx.f(I(x))→β​λx.f(x)=η​f​ The last step requires an extensional equality, which is the called eta-conversion. \text {for} \space x \not \in \text {FV} (f) , \lambda x.f(x) =_ \eta f for x∉FV(f),λx.f(x)=ηf \text {for} \space x \not \in \text {FV} (f) , \lambda x.f(x) =_ \eta f for x∈FV(f),λx.f(x)=η​f It makes more sense to use the equation from right to left called eta-expansion (And more discipline has to be imposed or expansion does not terminate).

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Non-termination

mainmatter.p: The well-known divergent combinator implies that the lambda calculus is not strongly normalizing.

However, we can always compute a normal form if one exists. Though there are many reduction strategies, there is a complete one for expressions that have normal form. This kind of reduction strategy is called normal order reduction or leftmost-outermost reduction. It scans through the expression from left to right and when it find a redex, it reduces it by applying beta reduction and returns to the beginning.
The notation of leftmost-outermost reduction is closely related to the notion of call-by-name evaluation in programming languages. (A little more distance to call-by-need evaluation in Haskell)
In contrast, call-by-value evaluation is not complete, which would reduce the argument of a function before applying beta reduction.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Church-Rosser Property

tree.mainmatter: The outcome of a computation eeee is its normal form. It is naturally to ask the question whether the normal form is unique. The key to this question is the Church-Rosser property or confluence: If e \to ^* e_1e→∗e1e \to ^* e_1e→∗e1​ and e \to ^* e_2e→∗e2e \to ^* e_2e→∗e2​, then there exists a term e_3e3e_3e3​ such that e_1 \to ^* e_3 \space \text {and} \space e_2 \to ^* e_3 e1→∗e3 and e2→∗e3 e_1 \to ^* e_3 \space \text {and} \space e_2 \to ^* e_3 e1​→∗e3​ and e2​→∗e3​ This implies the uniqueness of the normal form.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Representing Natural Numbers

mainmatter.p: We can represent natural numbers in lambda calculus by using the Church numerals or Church encoding. The two abstractions should be related in some ways: one xxxx stands for zero and the other ffff stands for the successor function.

The Church numeral nnnn is a function that takes two arguments ffff and xxxx and applies ffff to xxxx nnnn times. The Church numeral 0000 is defined as the identity function \lambda f. \lambda x.xλf.λx.x\lambda f. \lambda x.xλf.λx.x. The Church numeral 1111 is defined as the successor of 0000: 1 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(x) 1=λf.λx.f(x) 1 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(x) 1=λf.λx.f(x) The Church numeral 2222 is defined as the successor of 1111: 2 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(f(x)) 2=λf.λx.f(f(x)) 2 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(f(x)) 2=λf.λx.f(f(x)) And so on.

The Church numeral nnnn is defined as the successor of n-1n−1n-1n−1: n = \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) n=λf.λx.fn(x) n = \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) n=λf.λx.fn(x) where f^n(x)fn(x)f^n(x)fn(x) means applying ffff to xxxx nnnn times.

The successor function is defined as follows: S = \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) S=λn.λf.λx.f(n f x) S = \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) S=λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)

mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} S \space n &= ( \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)) \space n \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) \\ & \to _ \beta n+1 \end {align*} S n=(λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)) n→βλf.λx.f(n f x)→βλf.λx.fn(x)→βn+1 \begin {align*} S \space n &= ( \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)) \space n \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) \\ & \to _ \beta n+1 \end {align*} S n​=(λn.λf.λx.f(n f x)) n→β​λf.λx.f(n f x)→β​λf.λx.fn(x)→β​n+1​

mainmatter.p: Using the iteration property we can define mathematical functions over the natural numbers in lambda calculus. The addition of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined as follows: m+n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space S \space k m+n=λn.λk.n S k m+n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space S \space k m+n=λn.λk.n S k

The multiplication of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined by iterating the addition function mmmm times: m*n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space (k + ) \space 0 m∗n=λn.λk.n (k+) 0 m*n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space (k + ) \space 0 m∗n=λn.λk.n (k+) 0

The exponentiation of two Church numerals mmmm and nnnn is defined as follows: m^n = \lambda m. \lambda n. n \space (m *) \space 1 mn=λm.λn.n (m∗) 1 m^n = \lambda m. \lambda n. n \space (m *) \space 1 mn=λm.λn.n (m∗) 1

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › The Schema of Iteration

mainmatter.p: As we saw before, a natural number nnnn is represented by a function that iterates its first argument nnnn times on its second argument. n = \lambda g. \lambda c.g^n(c) n=λg.λc.gn(c) n = \lambda g. \lambda c.g^n(c) n=λg.λc.gn(c) Another way to specify such a function schematically is \begin {align*} f \space0 &= c \\ f (n+1) &= g \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0=cf(n+1)=g (f n) \begin {align*} f \space0 &= c \\ f (n+1) &= g \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0f(n+1)​=c=g (f n)​ If such a function satisfies such a schema of iteration, then it can be defined in the lambda calculus on Church numerals as f = \lambda n.n \space g \space c f=λn.n g c f = \lambda n.n \space g \space c f=λn.n g c This definition is total which means it is defined for all natural numbers. Let's define the multiplication again \begin {align*} m*0 &= 0 \\ m*(n+1) &= m + (m*n) \end {align*} m∗0=0m∗(n+1)=m+(m∗n) \begin {align*} m*0 &= 0 \\ m*(n+1) &= m + (m*n) \end {align*} m∗0m∗(n+1)​=0=m+(m∗n)​ To fit our schema of iteration, we can define the multiplication by abstracting over kkkk: \begin {align*} \text {times} \space 0 &= \lambda k.0 \\ \text {times} \space (n+1) &= \lambda k.k + ( \text {times} \space n \space k) \end {align*} times 0=λk.0times (n+1)=λk.k+(times n k) \begin {align*} \text {times} \space 0 &= \lambda k.0 \\ \text {times} \space (n+1) &= \lambda k.k + ( \text {times} \space n \space k) \end {align*} times 0times (n+1)​=λk.0=λk.k+(times n k)​ where the cccc and gggg are \begin {align*} c &= \lambda k.0 \\ g &= \lambda r. \lambda k.k+(r \space k) \end {align*} c=λk.0g=λr.λk.k+(r k) \begin {align*} c &= \lambda k.0 \\ g &= \lambda r. \lambda k.k+(r \space k) \end {align*} cg​=λk.0=λr.λk.k+(r k)​ and we obtain \text {times} = \lambda n.n( \lambda rk. k + (r \space k))( \lambda k.0) times=λn.n(λrk.k+(r k))(λk.0) \text {times} = \lambda n.n( \lambda rk. k + (r \space k))( \lambda k.0) times=λn.n(λrk.k+(r k))(λk.0)

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › The Schema of Primitive Recursion

mainmatter.p: Everything appears simply until we think of a very simple function, the predecessor function \text {pred}pred\text {pred}pred defined by \begin {align*} \text {pred} \space 0 = 0 \\ \text {pred} \space (n+1) = n \end {align*} pred 0=0pred (n+1)=n \begin {align*} \text {pred} \space 0 = 0 \\ \text {pred} \space (n+1) = n \end {align*} pred 0=0pred (n+1)=n​ What we would need is the schema of primitive recursion \begin {align*} f \space 0 &= c \\ f \space (n+1) &= g \space n \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0=cf (n+1)=g n (f n) \begin {align*} f \space 0 &= c \\ f \space (n+1) &= g \space n \space (f \space n) \end {align*} f 0f (n+1)​=c=g n (f n)​ With which we can define the predecessor function by g = \lambda x. \lambda y.x g=λx.λy.x g = \lambda x. \lambda y.x g=λx.λy.x

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Define predecessor function

tree.mainmatter: The key idea is to gain access to nnnn in the schema of primitive recursion by rebuilding it during the iteration. \text {pred}_2 \space n = \langle n, \text {pred} \space n \rangle pred2 n=⟨n,pred n⟩ \text {pred}_2 \space n = \langle n, \text {pred} \space n \rangle pred2​ n=⟨n,pred n⟩ The key step is to express the definition by a schema of iteration rather than primitive recursion. \text {pred}_2 \space 0 = \langle 0, 0 \rangle pred2 0=⟨0,0⟩ \text {pred}_2 \space 0 = \langle 0, 0 \rangle pred2​ 0=⟨0,0⟩ We need a helper function for the successor case \text {letPair} \space \langle e_1,e_2 \rangle \space k = k \space e_1 \space e_2 letPair ⟨e1,e2⟩ k=k e1 e2 \text {letPair} \space \langle e_1,e_2 \rangle \space k = k \space e_1 \space e_2 letPair ⟨e1​,e2​⟩ k=k e1​ e2​ This function passes the elements of the pair to a continuation kkkk. \text {pred}_2 (n+1) = \text {letPair} \space ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, x \rangle ) pred2(n+1)=letPair (pred2 n) (λxy.⟨x+1,x⟩) \text {pred}_2 (n+1) = \text {letPair} \space ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, x \rangle ) pred2​(n+1)=letPair (pred2​ n) (λxy.⟨x+1,x⟩)

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Define Pairs

tree.mainmatter: Now we need to define pairs and \text {letPair}letPair\text {letPair}letPair. The idea is to simply abstract over the continuation itself. \begin {align*} \langle x,y \rangle &= \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {pair} &= \lambda x. \lambda y. \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {letPair} &= \lambda p.p \end {align*} ⟨x,y⟩=λk.k x ypair=λx.λy.λk.k x yletPair=λp.p \begin {align*} \langle x,y \rangle &= \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {pair} &= \lambda x. \lambda y. \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {letPair} &= \lambda p.p \end {align*} ⟨x,y⟩pairletPair​=λk.k x y=λx.λy.λk.k x y=λp.p​ The letPair is not really needed here.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › Summary

tree.mainmatter: Summarizing the above and we obtain the full definition of the predecessor function. \begin {align*} \text {pred}_2 &= \lambda n.n \space ( \lambda p.p ( \lambda xy. \text {pair} \space (x+1) \space x)) \space \text {pair} ( \space 0 \space 0) \\ \text {pred} &= \lambda n. ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} pred2=λn.n (λp.p(λxy.pair (x+1) x)) pair( 0 0)pred=λn.(pred2 n) (λxy.y) \begin {align*} \text {pred}_2 &= \lambda n.n \space ( \lambda p.p ( \lambda xy. \text {pair} \space (x+1) \space x)) \space \text {pair} ( \space 0 \space 0) \\ \text {pred} &= \lambda n. ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} pred2​pred​=λn.n (λp.p(λxy.pair (x+1) x)) pair( 0 0)=λn.(pred2​ n) (λxy.y)​

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus › General Primitive Recursion

tree.mainmatter: The general case of primitive recursion follows by a similar pattern. We begin by defining a function f_2f2f_2f2​: f_2 \space n = \langle n, f \space n \rangle f2 n=⟨n,f n⟩ f_2 \space n = \langle n, f \space n \rangle f2​ n=⟨n,f n⟩ We can define f_2f2f_2f2​ using the schema of iteration \begin {align*} f_2 \space 0 &= \langle 0, c \rangle \\ f_2 \space (n+1) &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, g \space x \space y \rangle ) \\ f \space n &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} f2 0=⟨0,c⟩f2 (n+1)=letPair (f2 n) (λxy.⟨x+1,g x y⟩)f n=letPair (f2 n) (λxy.y) \begin {align*} f_2 \space 0 &= \langle 0, c \rangle \\ f_2 \space (n+1) &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, g \space x \space y \rangle ) \\ f \space n &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*} f2​ 0f2​ (n+1)f n​=⟨0,c⟩=letPair (f2​ n) (λxy.⟨x+1,g x y⟩)=letPair (f2​ n) (λxy.y)​

mainmatter.p: When computing over natural numbers we can restrict the functions that can be formed in schematic ways to obtain a language in which all functions terminate. Because if cccc and gggg are terminating then so is ffff formed from them by primitive recursion.
